author: Bloomberg.com
title: ‘Pan’ Lacks Box-Office Magic in Third-Place Debut for Retelling
text:
“Pan,” Warner Bros.’ new $150 million spin on the classic fairy tale, opened in third place in North American theaters, a disappointing debut for a film based on a well-known children’s character.
The live-action movie, featuring Hugh Jackman as the pirate Blackbeard and Levi Miller as Peter Pan, posted weekend tickets sales of $15.5 million, researcher Rentrak Corp. said Sunday in an e-mailed statement. “The Martian,” starring Matt Damon, led the box office with $37 million in its second weekend.
The slow start for “Pan” shows even classic stories are no sure thing with fickle movie audiences, a warning sign to studios that mine old stories for ideas to revisit. While Walt Disney Co. and Sony Pictures have produced successful Peter Pan movies, Warner Bros. isn’t so lucky.
“When you talk about fairy tales, if it’s not under the Disney brand, it’s a tough sell,” Jeff Bock, senior box office analyst at Exhibitor Relations Co., said before weekend results were announced. “They can’t tap into it in the same way Disney does.”
The effects-laden film had been forecast by researcher BoxOffice.com to open with sales of $16.5 million and $46 million in its full domestic run. Even with foreign sales, it will be hard for Time Warner Inc.’s film division to recoup its costs. The picture opens on Oct. 12 in China, the world’s No. 2 movie market and one of a few possible bright spots for the picture.
Both Imdb.com and Box Office Mojo had put the film’s production budget at $150 million, a sum that doesn’t include money the studio spent advertising the picture.
